Package gold_miner

Class GameMaster

java.lang.Object
gold_miner.GameMaster
public class GameMaster
extends java.lang.Object
Class implementing the game master of this pathfinding system, the central class that provides access to all the methods necessary to run the system

Note that the row and column numbers in this class (as well as in all other classes responsible for the back-end behavior) are zero-based.

  • Field Summary

    Fields 
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    static char FAST
    Character code specifying that the actions of the miner are shown automatically, that is, the next action is displayed after a set duration of pause, without the need for a button click from the user
    static char RANDOM
    Character code specifying that the agent (miner) is nonrational, that its, its actions are randomly decided as long as it does not result in the miner going out of bounds
    static char RATIONAL
    Character code specifying that the agent (miner) is rational, that is, its actions are deliberated via more sophisticated decision-making processes (explained in the technical report accompanying this program)
    static char STEP_BY_STEP
    Character code specifying that the actions of the miner are shown in a step-by-step fashion, that is, the next action is not displayed until the pertinent button is clicked by the user

    Creates a game master object

  • Constructor Details

    • GameMaster

      public GameMaster()
      Creates a game master object

      Since initialization of attributes depends on the choice made by the user, it is deferred and delegated to the setters, particularly to initGame, setAIMode, and setSystemMode.

  • Method Details

    • initGame

      public void initGame​(int dimension, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> rBeacon, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> cBeacon, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> rPit, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> cPit, int rGold, int cGold)
      Initializes the attributes of the board given the dimension, the row- and column- coordinates of the beacons, the row- and column-coordinates of the pits, and the row- and column-coordinates of the gold square tile
      Parameters:
      dimension - number of square tiles spanning the length of the board (which is also equal to the number of tiles spanning its width)
      rBeacon - row-coordinates of the beacons
      cBeacon - column-coordinates of the beacons
      rPit - row-coordinates of the pits
      cPit - column-coordinates of the pits
      rGold - row-coordinate of the gold square tile
      cGold - column-coordinate of the gold square tile

    • setAIMode

      public void setAIMode​(char mode)
      Sets the intelligence of the agent (miner) depending on the specified mode

      This method should only be invoked once. Once the mode has been set, then it is already immutable.

      The following are the possible modes:

      • Rational - The actions are deliberated via more sophisticated decision-making processes (explained in the technical report accompanying this program)
      • Nonrational - The actions are randomly decided as long as it does not result in the miner going out of bounds
      Parameters:
      mode - character code specifying the intelligence of the agent (miner)

    • setSystemMode

      public void setSystemMode​(char mode)
      Sets the speed at which the actions of the miner are shown depending on the specified mode

      This method should only be invoked once. Once the mode has been set, then it is already immutable.

      The following are the possible modes:

      • Step by step - The next action is not displayed until the pertinent button is clicked by the user
      • Fast - The next action is displayed after a set duration of pause, without the need for a button click from the user
      Parameters:
      mode - character code specifying the speed at which the actions of the miner are shown

    • getAIMode

      public char getAIMode()
      Returns the character code specifying the intelligence of the agent (miner)

      The following are the possible modes:

      • Rational - The actions are deliberated via more sophisticated decision-making processes (explained in the technical report accompanying this program)
      • Nonrational - The actions are randomly decided as long as it does not result in the miner going out of bounds
      Returns:
      character code specifying the intelligence of the agent (miner)

    • getSystemMode

      public char getSystemMode()
      Returns the character code specifying the speed at which the actions of the miner

      The following are the possible modes:

      • Step by step - The next action is not displayed until the pertinent button is clicked by the user
      • Fast - The next action is displayed after a set duration of pause, without the need for a button click from the user
      Returns:
      character code specifying the speed at which the actions of the miner are shown

    • getRandom

      public int getRandom​(int hi)
      Returns a random integer from 0 (inclusive) to the set upper bound (exclusive) for use in the naive decision-making of the nonrational agent

      Technically, the integer generated is pseudorandom since the library used for its generation is Java's ThreadLocalRandom. Nevertheless, this is sufficient for the purposes of this system.

      Parameters:
      hi - exclusive upper bound
      Returns:
      random integer from 0 (inclusive) to the set upper bound (exclusive)

    • getRandomOutOfBoundsTiles

      public java.lang.String getRandomOutOfBoundsTiles()
      Returns a string representation of the scanned out-of-bounds tiles

      Since the nonrational agent does not have a "memory" or record of scanned tiles, the return value of this function is always "N/A".

      Returns:
      string representation of the scanned out-of-bounds tiles
